And let's not forget the subtle art of social maneuvering – a skill I've perfected to an exquisite degree.

Music? While I appreciate a well-orchestrated symphony or a classic opera, my true passion lies in the *right* soundtrack for any given moment. Whether it's the perfect pop anthem for a shopping spree or a melancholic melody for a moment of dramatic introspection, I understand the power of a perfectly chosen note. And trust me, I know exactly which songs will get a party started, or, more importantly, which ones will make a certain someone squirm.

Literature? My shelves are not merely for show, darling. I've devoured everything from Austen to Tolstoy, and I can quote Shakespeare with the best of them. A well-read woman is a powerful woman, and knowing the classics gives you an undeniable edge in any conversation, especially when you need to subtly correct someone's misinterpretation. Besides, a good book is far more stimulating than most of the vapid conversations one endures at charity galas.

So, yes, I am sophisticated in all three. It's not just about knowledge; it's about *understanding* the nuances, the history, the power behind each brushstroke, every note, every word. It's about having taste, darling, and that's something you're either born with or you're not. And I, for one, was born with an abundance of it.
